text.3:
This verse explains the reason for the nullification of the reward for the deeds and actions of disbelievers, and the reasons for the acceptance and rewarding of the deeds and actions of believers. Allah nullifies the reward for the deeds and actions of disbelievers because they choose misguidance over truth, follow the temptations of Satan, follow their desires, and do not believe in Allah and His Messenger.

The key to the acceptance of a deed or action is faith in Allah and His Messenger. Those who believe are submissive and obedient to Allah, and all their deeds and actions are solely aimed at seeking Allah's pleasure. Therefore, Allah calms their hearts and minds and guides them to the straight path.

In addition to clearly explaining His attitude and actions towards disbelievers and believers, Allah makes parables, analogies, and illustrations for mankind by presenting various characteristics, actions, and beliefs of a person in his life and existence, as well as the consequences and rewards of their actions. In reality, those who want to understand and comprehend the wisdom behind the parables, analogies, and illustrations would certainly believe in Allah, but because the hearts, hearing, and sight of the disbelievers have been sealed and locked due to the evil they have committed, all these parables mean nothing to them.

From this verse, one can draw the conclusion that it has become a *sunatullah* (Allah's law) that cannot be denied by anyone, that the basis of all deeds and actions of a person that are pleasing to Allah is faith in Him, in Muhammad as His Messenger, in all that the Messenger brought, performing all His commands, and avoiding all His prohibitions. These are the actions that can bring reward, while actions that are not based on faith, *taqwa* (God-consciousness), and obedience to Him, have no reward in the sight of Allah, like foam floating on the surface of the water that appears and disappears without leaving a trace.
text.4:
This verse explains to the Muslims how to face the disbelievers in war. They must exert all their abilities and capabilities to destroy the enemy. They should prioritize the victory to be achieved on every battlefield and not prioritize capturing the enemy and seizing spoils of war. Capturing is done after they are defeated, because the disbelievers are constantly wanting to kill and destroy the Muslims and they cannot be trusted. They pretend to want peace, but their hearts and beliefs still want to destroy Islam and its followers at every opportunity they may have. After the war is over with victory in the hands of the Muslims, they may choose one of two things, namely whether to free the prisoners who have been captured or to free them by paying ransom by the enemy or by exchanging prisoners.

In another verse it is explained that the limit for Muslims to stop fighting the disbelievers of Mecca is until there is no more *fitnah*. Allah says:

And fight them until there is no fitnah and [until] the religion, all of it, is for Allah. And if they cease, then there is to be no aggression except against the oppressors. (al-Baqarah/2: 193)

Ibn 'Abbas said, "When the number of Muslims increased and their strength also increased, Allah revealed this verse, and the Messenger of Allah acted towards the prisoners in accordance with this verse, as did the caliphs who came after him."

From the verse above and the words of Ibn 'Abbas, the following can be understood:

1. This verse was revealed after the Battle of Badr because at the time of the battle the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prioritized ransom, such as redeeming with wealth or by ordering prisoners to teach reading and writing to the Muslims, so the Messenger received a reprimand from Allah.

2. This verse is a guide for the Messenger of Allah and the companions in resolving issues related to warfare and prisoners of war.

3. The command to kill the disbelievers in this verse is carried out in warfare, not outside of warfare. Therefore, it is natural that Allah commands the Muslims to kill their enemies in the raging war because the enemy themselves act likewise towards them. If Allah did not command this, of course the Muslims would hesitate to face the enemy who would kill them, so the enemy would have the opportunity to destroy them.

4. Allah does not command the Muslims to kill the disbelievers wherever they find them, but Allah only commands the Muslims to fight the disbelievers who intend to damage, slander, and destroy Islam and the Muslims. Towards disbelievers who are kind to Islam and the Muslims, the Muslims are obliged to be kind to them as well. Allah says:

Allah does not forbid you from those who do not fight you because of religion and do not expel you from your homes - from being righteous toward them and acting justly toward them. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly. Allah only forbids you from those who fight you because of religion and expel you from your homes and help [others] in expelling you - [He forbids] that you make allies of them. And whoever makes allies of them - then it is those who are the wrongdoers. (al-Mumtahanah/60: 8-9)

5. The head of state has a role in making decisions and policies in resolving warfare and prisoners of war. He must base his decisions on the interests of religion, the Muslims and humanity, and the benefit of the public in general.

Forcing prisoners to convert to Islam is not allowed because this action contradicts the word of Allah which prohibits Muslims from forcing others to embrace Islam. Allah says:

There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion. The right course has become clear from the wrong. So whoever disbelieves in Taghut and believes in Allah has grasped the most trustworthy handhold that will never break. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing. (al-Baqarah/2: 256)

Killing prisoners for the Muslims certainly has a basis. The prisoners who are killed are not ordinary prisoners, but are war criminals who have committed many evil deeds. If he lives, then his crimes in the war will continue for a long time.

Making prisoners slaves is a common practice by nations in the world before the arrival of Islam. After the arrival of Islam, the enemies of Islam made the Muslims they captured slaves. Basically, slavery is prohibited by Islam, but as a response to the actions of the disbelievers and to protect the feelings of the Muslims, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) allowed the Muslims to make the disbelievers they captured slaves. This means that if the disbelievers do not make the Muslims they capture slaves, then the Muslims should not make the disbelievers they capture slaves. Even though slavery occurs because of prisoners of war, in Islam there are many legal provisions related to efforts to free slaves, which is called *kaffarat*.

Islam is a religion of peace, not a religion that encourages war. If in Islamic history there are wars between Muslims and disbelievers, then these wars occurred because of defending Islam which the disbelievers wanted to eliminate, in addition to defending themselves from destruction. Since the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was appointed as a messenger, since then hostility arose from the polytheists of Mecca towards him and his followers. They did various ways to eradicate Islam and the Muslims, from gentle ways to the most severe. The peak of the actions of the polytheists of Mecca was plotting to kill the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) so Allah ordered him to migrate to Medina. After the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was in Medina, the hostility became more severe, so the Muslims were forced to fight them to defend their religion and themselves.

Upon the arrival of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in Medina, a peace agreement with the residents of the city, which included the Jews, was signed, but the peace agreement was violated by them. They even attempted to kill the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was forced to fight the Jews in Medina.

There are very many examples that can be put forward that prove that Islam is not spread through war, but through *dakwah* that is full of wisdom and prudence.

Towards prisoners of war, the attitude of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was very good. In a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari, his attitude is explained. Abu Hurairah said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent a cavalry to Nejed, so the cavalry captured a man from Bani Hanifah named Thumamah bin Uthal, he was tied to one of the pillars of the mosque. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to him, then said, 'What do you have, O Thumamah?' Thumamah replied, 'I have wealth, if you want to kill me, do it, and if you want to free me, then I thank you, if you want wealth, then ask for how much you want.' The next day the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) also said to him, 'What do you have, O Thumamah?' He replied, 'I have what I have told you.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, 'Release Thumamah's bonds.' Then Thumamah went near a date palm tree near the mosque, then bathed, then he entered the mosque, then declared, 'I acknowledge that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is His Messenger. By Allah, there was no one I hated most in this world other than you, now you have become the person I love most. By Allah, there was no religion I hated most other than your religion, so now your religion has become the religion I love most. By Allah, the country I hated most was your country, now your country has become the country I love most. Indeed, the cavalry has captured me, while I intended to perform *umrah*, what is your opinion?' Then the Messenger of Allah gave him good news and ordered him to perform *umrah*. When he arrived in Mecca, someone said to him, 'Do you feel longing?' Thumamah replied, 'No, but I have converted to Islam with Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).'"

From this hadith it can be understood that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was gentle to Thumamah, a prisoner of war. He gave him freedom, so he was attracted to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and Islam, therefore he declared himself to have converted to Islam.

If the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had been harsh to him, of course Thumamah would not have said the statement in the hadith. He would have harbored resentment towards the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and at every opportunity he would have tried to avenge himself.

Islam came to uphold the principles that must exist in the life and lives of humans, whether as individual beings or as social beings. Among these principles are *tauhid*, justice, humanity, and deliberation. By upholding these principles, humans will succeed in their task as Allah's caliph on earth. On the basis of all of this, all problems are resolved, including the problems of warfare and prisoners of war.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains what reward will be received by those who believe and strive in the way of Allah by saying, "For those who strive in the way of Allah to defend Islam, Allah will never reduce their reward in the slightest, even He will reward them with a multiplied reward. Regarding the reward for striving in the way of Allah, it is mentioned in a hadith as follows: ØªÙŽØ§It was narrated by al-Miqdam bin Ma'diyakrib, he said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say, 'Indeed, the one who dies as a martyr obtains nine things - or ten, namely he will be forgiven at the moment his blood first flows, sees his dwelling place in paradise, is adorned with the ornaments of faith, is spared from the torment of the grave, is married to *bidadari*, obtains security at the time of the great day of fear (the Day of Judgment), on his head is placed a crown of glory made of gems that is better than the world and its contents, is married to 92 wives from the *bidadari* group, and is given the right of intercession for 70 of his relatives.'" (Narrated by ath-Thabrani)
text.5: This verse explains that Allah will guide those who believe in carrying out works that are pleasing to Him so that those works are successful, and He will protect them from committing disobedience and sinful acts. Allah also provides for them a place of return in Paradise that they already know because Allah shows them those places.
text.6: In this verse, it is explained that Allah will guide those who believe in carrying out works that are pleasing to Him so that those works are successful, and He will protect them from committing disobedience and sinful acts. Allah also provides for them a place of return in Paradise that they already know because Allah shows them those places.
text.7: Allah calls upon the believers that if they defend and help His religion by sacrificing their wealth and lives, then surely He will help them against their enemies. Allah will strengthen their hearts and their ranks in carrying out the obligation of defending the religion of Islam by fighting the disbelievers who seek to destroy it, so that the religion of Allah will stand firm and strong.
text.8: Furthermore, it is explained that those who do not believe in Allah, deny His oneness and power, will be doomed. Allah will erase all the rewards of their deeds and actions. Their actions will not receive guidance and *taufik* from Allah. Allah will also thwart all their schemes to destroy the Muslims.
text.9: This verse explains that Allah does not reward the deeds and actions of disbelievers, nor does He grant them guidance and His *taufiq* because they deny the guidance of the Qur'an that has been revealed to Prophet Muhammad as His messenger.
text.10:
The polytheists of Mecca who denied the prophethood and apostleship of Muhammad (peace be upon him), and rejected the truth of the guidance of the Qur'an as a book originating from Allah the Almighty, actually had various proofs to justify his prophethood and apostleship, because the land was located around the lands of previous peoples who had denied and rejected the call of the messengers of Allah. Did they not often go to Syria, north of their land, and Hadramaut, in the south? Did they not also go to Persia in the east and to Ethiopia in the southwest of their land? Their travels to these countries were for the purpose of trade.

On that journey, they passed through the remnants of the ruins of the land of the people of 'Ad, the people of Thamud, the people of Shu'aib, and so on, who had been destroyed by Allah. They could still see traces of that land in the form of debris, relics, and so on. They could witness these ruins, because the land was a commercial center at that time and was located on a trade route connecting the western world with the east. They also knew that the previous peoples had been destroyed by Allah because of their disobedience to Him and His Messenger. However, they did not want to pay attention and contemplate that *sunnatullah* (Allah's law/way) applies to everyone who denies His religion.

Therefore, the polytheists of Mecca will experience the same fate as that experienced by previous peoples if they continue to ignore the call of the Prophet Muhammad. As proof of the truth of Allah's promise, many polytheists of Mecca were killed in the Battle of Badr and also in the battles that followed.
text.11: This verse explains the state of the believers and the disbelievers in the world and the reason why the polytheists are afflicted with calamity. The polytheists have no helper to ward off the torment that befalls them, while the believers have a helper, namely Allah, the All-Powerful and the All-Helper.
text.12:
This verse speaks about the state of believers and disbelievers in the afterlife. Those who believe and do good deeds are given manifold rewards in the form of Paradise as a recompense for their faith and obedience. Meanwhile, those who deny the power and oneness of Allah and reject His Messenger, are influenced by the pleasures of life in this world, which are only temporary. They do not take lessons from the events that have befallen past nations. They are likened to animals that eat in a pen or in a pasture provided for them. These animals never think about whether the food available to them will still be there to eat tomorrow or whether it will all be used up today, so that there will be no food to eat again.

This verse provides a picture of the state and what the polytheists think about. They only think about what is delicious and can fulfill their desires. They do not want to think about how long they can enjoy the deliciousness and desires, and what the source of that deliciousness and pleasure is. Whether they can continue to enjoy it, they never think about. They also do not think about the consequences they will experience if they are no longer able to feel that pleasure. They feel the pleasure of eating something, but it never occurs to them that Allah has bestowed a tongue upon them to feel the pleasure of something eaten. What would happen if Allah gave them a disease of the tongue, so that they could no longer feel anything? They do not think about the best attitude and actions they should take towards the source of that pleasure.

The people described in the verse above, their place of return is Hell Jahannam, because that is the most fitting place of return for those who do not use their minds.
text.13:
It was narrated by 'Abd bin Humaid, Abu Ya'la, Ibn Abi Hatim, and Ibn Mardawaih from Ibn 'Abbas, that when the Prophet Muhammad was about to leave Mecca, before migrating to Medina, he turned back looking at the city of Mecca and said, "You (Mecca) are the land of Allah that I love the most, and if your people had not driven me out, I would not have left you." Then this verse was revealed.

In this verse, Allah gives a comparison as a consolation to the Prophet Muhammad, who had been troubled by the attitudes and actions of the polytheists of Mecca. It is explained that how many cities whose inhabitants were stronger in body, had more knowledge, were more capable of building their cities, had more soldiers so that they could conquer the surrounding lands compared to the polytheists of Mecca. All of them have been destroyed by Allah with various kinds of disasters that befell them. In facing these disasters, they had no helpers whatsoever. All the strength, power, and mighty armies were of no use at all in facing these disasters. The polytheists of Mecca will experience a similar fate if they continue to deny the call of the Prophet Muhammad. Therefore, the Prophet is urged to be patient and steadfast in facing their attitudes and actions, and Allah will surely help and give victory to His servants who are obedient to Him.
text.14:
This verse explains the comparison between believers and disbelievers by saying, "Is the one who is willing to think, so that he has understanding, comprehension, and conviction regarding the religion of Allah and the Qur'an revealed to Muhammad, peace be upon him, the same as those who are unwilling to use their minds, so that they do not believe that Allah will give a fitting reward to those who follow their desires and the temptations of Satan? Of course, these two types of people are not the same; in fact, the difference between them is very great."

In another verse, Allah says:

"Then is one who knows that what has been revealed to you from your Lord is the truth like one who is blind? Only those of understanding will be reminded." (ar-Ra'd/13: 19)

And the word of Allah:

"Not equal are the companions of the Fire and the companions of Paradise. It is the companions of Paradise who will be the attainers [of success]." (al-Hashr/59: 20)
text.15:
The reward that believers will obtain in the afterlife is not the same as the reward that non-believers will obtain. This verse depicts the state of Paradise and Hell in a very interesting symbolic form. It begins with the word "perumpamaan" (matsalul jannati - the parable of Paradise). First, "Paradise," and the second "perumpamaan" (parable), "samakah" (kaman - is it the same?) which is summarized in a questioning tone. Az-Zamakhsyari said (in al-Kasysyaf), this expression is in the form of affirmation, but in reality, it is a denial, a negation.

The characteristics of Paradise explained in this verse include: first, rivers flow abundantly within it, and each river has water of various types and tastes, and is delicious to drink for the inhabitants of Paradise. Among the types of water are:

1. Some are clear and clean, not contaminated by anything. Therefore, the taste, color, and smell will not change.

2. There are rivers that flow with milk that is good to drink. The milk remains good and delicious, and its taste will not change due to spoilage or decay.

3. There are rivers that flow with wine that is delicious to drink, healthy, and refreshing for the body and feelings of the drinker. Unlike wine in the world. Even though it is delicious to drink for addicts, it can damage the body, mind, and thoughts. Therefore, wine in Paradise is halal to drink, while wine in the world is haram.

4. There are rivers that flow with pure honey, like honey that has been filtered, delicious, and healthy for the drinker's body.

Narrated by Ahmad, at-Tirmidhi, and others from Mu'awiyah bin haidah, he said:

I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say, "In Paradise there is a sea of milk, a sea of water, a sea of honey, and a sea of wine, then rivers flow from those seas." (Riwayat Ahmad, at-Tirmidhi, dan lain-lain dari Mu'awiyah bin haidah - Narrated by Ahmad, at-Tirmidhi, and others from Mu'awiyah bin haidah)

Second, in Paradise there are fruits of various kinds, different in color, shape, and taste. All of them are delicious food for every inhabitant of Paradise.

Third, the inhabitants of Paradise are people who are clean from all blemishes and sins, because they have been forgiven by Allah, the Most Merciful Lord, their Protector.

Then Allah explains the condition of those who live in Hell. They drink very hot water that destroys their intestines and the fire of Hell that burns their faces to ashes.
text.16:
This verse explains that when the Prophet Muhammad recited the Al-Qur'an, among those who listened were hypocrites, but they did not understand his recitation. After they left the Prophet, they asked the Prophet's companions who were knowledgeable and understood all his words, "What did Muhammad say in the meeting earlier?" This question was something that was of no benefit.

Their purpose in doing so was none other than to mock the words of the Messenger of Allah. They acted as if they understood his words, so they asked questions and gave responses, saying that what the Messenger of Allah said had no meaning whatsoever for them.

It is narrated by Muqatil that the Prophet Muhammad gave a sermon and explained the bad character of the hypocrites, and among those who listened to the sermon were also hypocrites. After the sermon was over, the hypocrites went out and asked 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud with the intention of mocking and belittling the Messenger of Allah. Among them, they said, "What did Muhammad say earlier?" Ibn 'Abbas said, "I was also once asked a question like that."

Then the verse explains why the hypocrites did such a thing. Those people whose characteristics have been described are those whose hearts have been sealed and locked, so that they can no longer receive the guidance and truth that has been conveyed to them.
text.17: This verse explains the condition of people who are the opposite of the hypocrites. They are those who have received guidance, believe, listen, pay attention to, and practice the verses of the Qur'an. Allah expands their chests, their hearts become tranquil when they listen to the verses of the Qur'an or when they recite them, and their knowledge of the religion of Allah increases. Allah increases their guidance further through inspiration and guides them to perform righteous deeds, and gives them the ability to increase their obedience and piety (taqwa).
text.18:
Those whose hearts have been sealed and locked shut, so that they can no longer accept truth and guidance, are people whose lives are no longer beneficial. They are only waiting for death and the arrival of the Day of Judgment, which comes suddenly. When the Day of Judgment has come, and its signs have indeed appeared, then reminders are of no use to them, and Allah will not accept their repentance, and even faith and good deeds are of no use to them. Allah says:

And on that Day Hell will be brought [forth]. On that Day man will remember, but what good to him will be the remembrance? (al-Fajr/89: 23)
text.19:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad, when he is certain and knows the reward that believers will obtain, as well as the punishment that disbelievers will receive in the afterlife, to hold fast to the religion of Allah which can bring happiness in life in this world and the hereafter. He is also commanded to ask Allah to forgive his sins and the sins of the believers, to always pray and remember Him, and never to give Satan the opportunity to carry out his evil intentions towards him.

A sahih hadith says that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) always prayed:

"O Allah, forgive my mistakes, my ignorance, and my excesses in my affairs, and my sins that You know better than I do. O Allah, forgive my frivolous words and my serious words, my mistakes, my intentional actions, and everything that is in me." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Musa al-Asy'ari)

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) often prayed at the end of his prayer, before saying the salam:

"O Allah, forgive my past and future sins, my hidden and manifest sins, my excessive actions, and my sins that You know better than I do. You are my Lord, there is no god but You." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Abbas)

O people, repent to your Lord, for indeed I ask forgiveness of Allah and repent to Him more than seventy times every day. (Narrated by Muslim)

Abu Bakar as-Siddiq said, "You should read, "La ilaha illallah and istighfar." Read both repeatedly, for indeed Iblis says, "I destroy humans with their sinful deeds, and they destroy me by reading La ilaha illallah and istighfar, so when I know that, I destroy them with their desires, and they think they are guided." (Narrated by Abu Ya'la).

In one athar it is explained the words of Iblis, "By Your might and majesty, O Lord, I will always deceive them as long as their souls are in their bodies." Then Allah said, "By My might and majesty, I will always forgive their sins, as long as they continue to ask Me for forgiveness."

Furthermore, Allah encourages people to carry out His commands, avoid His prohibitions, and always strive to seek sustenance and happiness in their lives. Allah says, "He knows all their efforts, behaviors, and actions during the day, as well as where they are at night. Therefore, fear Him and ask for His forgiveness." In another verse, Allah says:

And there is no creature on earth but that upon Allah is its provision, and He knows its place of dwelling and place of storage. All is in a clear register. (Hud/11: 6)

And it is He who takes your souls by night and knows what you have committed by day. Then He revives you therein that a specified term may be fulfilled. Then to Him will be your return; then He will inform you about what you used to do. (al-An'am/6: 60)
text.20:
Those who believe in Allah and His Messenger with sincerity are certainly willing to sacrifice their wealth and lives in the path of Allah. They eagerly await the revelation of Allah, especially revelations related to the command of jihad. However, the command to fight is fundamentally not for aggression, but for self-defense against enemy attacks, as happened in the Battle of Badr, the Battle of Uhud, the Battle of Khandak, and others. They said, "Why does Allah not send down to us verses that are firm and clear in meaning, which state that fighting to defend the religion of Allah is a mandatory command that must be carried out by every believer?" Conversely, the hypocrites behave differently. When a verse is revealed that is firm and clear in meaning, containing the command of jihad, they look at the Prophet with an expression of denial and fear. Their hearts shrink, their bodies tremble upon hearing it, and they are silent, like someone facing the moment of death.

In another verse, Allah says:

"Have you not seen those who were told, 'Restrain your hands (from fighting), establish prayer, and give zakat'? But when fighting was ordained for them, at once a party of them feared men (i.e., the enemy) as they fear Allah or with (even) greater fear. They said, 'Our Lord, why have You ordained fighting for us? Why could You not have delayed us for a short time?' Say, 'Enjoyment of this world is little, and the Hereafter is better for he who fears Allah. And injustice will not be done to you, [even] as much as a thread [in a date seed].'" (an-Nisa'/4: 77)

From the answers and attitudes of the hypocrites, what is implied in their hearts is revealed. Such a person is better off dead than living while restraining themselves from the commands of religion. A person lives to be a servant of Allah who is obedient to Him, wanting to achieve happiness in this world and the Hereafter. The hypocrites do not carry out that obedience. They seem not to think about the happiness of life after death. Therefore, life has no meaning for them other than to multiply deeds of sin that cause them to be punished in the Hereafter. If they die at that moment, their punishment will not increase in the Hereafter.
text.21:
This verse explains the attitude that hypocrites should have: obedience to Allah, uttering good words ( _qaul ma'ruf_ ), rather than fear and trepidation in the face of the enemy. However, they are not like that. This is because the pleasures of life in this world have captivated them and made them forget themselves. They are afraid of losing these pleasures. Whereas, if they knew that the pleasures of life in this world are illusory and temporary, while the pleasures of life in the Hereafter are the true pleasures, surely they would change their attitude.

Furthermore, it is explained that when an order to fight comes, hatred arises in the hearts of the hypocrites, so they are reluctant to participate in the battle. If they had strong faith in their hearts, truly obeyed Allah and followed the Messenger, they would surely participate in the battle alongside the Messenger. That would be better for them because in that way they would be closer to Allah.
text.22: This verse censures the attitude of the hypocrites who are always pursuing the pleasures of worldly life, by saying, "O hypocrites, because you are always pursuing the pleasures of worldly life and its luxuries, if you were in power, you would surely have the characteristics of wanting to prioritize yourselves by showing off your power to the common people, liking to take and violate the rights of others, and severing the ties of kinship which are highly encouraged to be maintained."
text.23: The hypocrites who behave as mentioned above have been distanced by Allah from His mercy. Therefore, Allah has deprived them of their hearing so that they cannot learn from what they can hear, and Allah has blinded them so that they cannot benefit from what they see.
text.24:
Do the hypocrites not observe and understand the teachings of Allah contained in the Qur'an, nor reflect and contemplate upon them, so that they may know the error of their attitudes and actions thus far? Or have their hearts and sight been locked so that they can no longer understand its contents?

The attitudes and actions carried out by the hypocrites were not only directed towards believers, but also towards the Jews. They declared their willingness to cooperate with the Jewish tribes of Bani Nadhir and Bani Quraidzah. They were even willing to follow some of the desires of the Jews to win their hearts, but all these promises and willingness were not kept. They sometimes did not hesitate to harm the friends they conspired with, betraying their allies.

Allah says:

"Have you not seen those who hypocritically say to their brothers who disbelieve among the People of the Scripture, "If you are expelled, we will surely leave with you, and we will not obey, ever, anyone concerning you; and if you are fought, we will surely aid you." And Allah is witness that they are liars." (al-hasyr/59: 11)
text.25: This verse explains that those who revert to disbelief after the straight path has become clear to them, engaging in sinful and misguided actions, are those who have been consumed and influenced by the deception of Satan. Satan makes the sinful and misguided actions they commit appear good in their eyes, so they live wallowing in sin and error. In addition to this, they are lulled by false hopes, in accordance with the impulses of their desires. Thus, their desires become the measure of good or bad deeds. What their desires deem good, they consider good. These are the things that give rise to hypocrisy within them.
text.26:
The hypocrites reverted to disbelief, even though they had previously appeared to believe, because they sided with and allied themselves with the Jews from the Bani Nadhir and Bani Quraidzah to fight against the believers. The hypocrites declared that they would participate in the war on the side of the Bani Nadhir and Bani Quraidzah against the Muslims if the Jewish tribes were expelled from Medina.

The Jews had once encouraged the hypocrites to openly display their disbelief. However, they did not comply with that encouragement, except in some matters. Among the things they did not comply with was the encouragement to openly declare their disbelief. They kept their disbelief secret because they still hoped for profit by concealing it. However, Allah knows the actions they conceal, because nothing is unknown to Him. In another verse, Allah explains how they orchestrate their strategies and deceptions. Allah says:

And they (the hypocrites) say, "(We hear and obey)." But when they leave you (Muhammad), a group of them spend the night in devising plans different from what you say. But Allah records what they plot by night. So turn aside from them and rely upon Allah. And Allah is sufficient as Trustee. (an-Nisa'/4: 81)
text.27:
This verse continues to speak about the hypocrites, and what they will do if they remain in that hypocrisy. They can only practice hypocrisy and deception while they are alive, in power, and in a state of physical and spiritual health. What do they think will happen when Allah suddenly removes their health, and old age gradually approaches their lives? What do they think will happen when death approaches them and the angel of death strikes their faces and backs; what will they do? What do they think will happen if they die suddenly, so that they have no opportunity whatsoever to repent to Allah, who determines everything in the Hereafter? If they thought about and contemplated all of this, surely they would not commit acts of disbelief and sin.

This verse mentions that when the angels are about to take their souls, the angels will extract their souls forcefully and harshly, and strike their faces and backs. The Arabs are very afraid of being struck in the face and back. Because they are afraid of being struck by the enemy in the face and back, they do not want to go to war. This verse shows the state of the hypocrites in a state of misery and humiliation when facing the throes of death (sakaratul maut). Allah says:

And if you could but see when the angels take the souls of those who disbelieve, striking their faces and their backs (al-Anfal/8: 50)
text.28: They experience such a state because they frequently commit sins, constantly disbelieve in Allah, follow their desires, and are unwilling to do deeds that please Him. They worship Allah only for ostentation (riya) and to be appreciated by people. Therefore, all the deeds they perform, such as giving charity and helping the weak, poor, and miserable, are of no use or benefit. This is because good deeds and actions are only accepted if they are based on faith in Allah and His Messenger.
text.29:
Do the hypocrites think that their animosity and evil intentions towards the believers, hidden in their hearts, will not be known? Do they think that Allah does not know it, so He will not inform His Messenger and the believers? Allah, the All-Knowing of everything, will inform His believing servants about all their evil secrets.

Regarding the secrets and evil plans of the hypocrites, it is explained at length in Surah at-Taubah. Among them is the word of Allah:

The hypocrite men and women are of one another. They enjoin what is wrong and forbid what is right and close their hands [from spending]. They have forgotten Allah, so He has forgotten them [also]. Indeed, the hypocrites - it is they who are the defiantly disobedient. (at-Taubah/9: 67)
text.30:
In this verse, Allah states to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), "O Muhammad, if We willed to introduce to you the individuals of the hypocrites so that you would know each one of them based on the signs that are on them, it would certainly not be difficult for Us to do so. However, We do not do so, so that their families who believe in Us are not wronged by them. Even so, you can know the hypocrites by observing their expressions and the ways they speak. They do not want to speak firmly and clearly, but always use hints and allusions as well as metaphors whose meanings are unclear, and they act and behave inconsistently with what they say."

In the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when hypocrites spoke, they always used grand and pleasing words to the listeners, but in their hearts, they harbored evil intentions. Al-Kalbi said, "After this verse was revealed, the Messenger of Allah knew the hypocrites when they spoke to him." While Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) said, "Allah informed the Messenger of Allah about the hypocrites through revelation or through signs that He showed to him."

Regarding the hypocrites, 'Uthman bin 'Affan said, "There is no secret hidden in a person's heart, except that Allah reveals it on their facial expressions and outward speech."

At the end of this verse, Allah states that the condition of the believers is not the same as that of the hypocrites. He will reward the deeds of the believers according to their respective intentions and purposes, because Allah knows their deeds.
text.31: With the establishment of the rules of war and other heavy obligations, Allah tests the faith of the Muslims so that it is known who strives in His path and who does not, and who is patient and who is not. Through this trial, the faith of those who are patient will become stronger, and the faith of those who are doubtful will diminish.
text.32:
This verse explains that those who deny the Oneness of Allah, hinder people from embracing His religion brought by Prophet Muhammad, oppose and fight against it after strong evidence has been presented to them, then all their actions will not cause harm to Allah or to the development of His religion because Allah is All-Powerful and His will is certainly fulfilled. He helps His Messenger in the world and punishes everyone who opposes Him. In the Hereafter, all their efforts will not succeed in the slightest.

"Those who hinder people from the path of Allah" mentioned in this verse refers to those who prevent others from entering Islam in various ways. It can also mean those who try to destroy Islam and the Muslims, both openly and secretly.

It is narrated that this verse was revealed in connection with the Jews from Bani Quraidzah and Bani Nadhir. They hindered people from embracing the religion of Allah after clear evidence had come to them, which was found in the Torah and the miracles presented by the Messenger of Allah. Their actions will not benefit them in the slightest against Allah's plan and will, but will instead destroy themselves, with the failure of all their efforts, and the punishment they receive in the Hereafter.

This verse is also related to the Jews who hindered Bani Sa'ad who had embraced Islam, and then they complained about it to Prophet Muhammad. He answered the complaint with this verse, which states that the actions of the Jews will not harm Allah, but will harm themselves.
text.33:
In this verse, Allah asks those who believe to obey Him and His Messenger and not to disregard the attitudes and actions of the disbelievers. They should believe, acknowledge the oneness and power of Allah who possesses perfect attributes, obey His commands, implement His teachings, and not violate His commands, which would cause the loss of the reward for the deeds they perform.

According to Abu al-'Aliyah, "Initially, the companions believed that no sin could invalidate a person's declaration that "there is no god but Allah," just as no deed based on shirk would be beneficial, until this verse was revealed. After the revelation of this verse, the companions became worried that their deeds would be nullified by a sinful act."

Ibn 'Umar said, "We, all the companions of the Messenger of Allah (saw), believed that good deeds would be accepted by Allah until this verse was revealed. After this verse was revealed, we asked, 'What are the things that invalidate the reward of our deeds?' Then the Messenger of Allah (saw) answered, 'Major sins, evil deeds, and vile acts.' After that, if one of us committed a sin (zina) mentioned above, we would say, 'Indeed, the reward for his deeds has been erased,' until the verse was revealed which means, 'Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills.' After that, we did not discuss the matter anymore."

Some commentators are of the opinion that obeying Allah means practicing the contents of the Al-Qur'an. While obeying the Messenger means following and implementing all the commands and prohibitions contained in his hadith.
text.34:
This verse explains that those who deny the power and oneness of Allah, deny the call of His Messenger, hinder people from His path, and then die in a state of disbelief, then Allah will never forgive their sins because the door to repentance and forgiveness from Allah is only available while still alive in this world. If someone has died, then everything is closed to them.

Some scholars of tafsir explain that this verse was revealed in connection with the disbelievers who died in the Battle of Badr and were buried in a well. Regardless of the truth or falsehood of that opinion, this verse applies to all people, wherever and whenever, that anyone who dies in a state of disbelief, Allah will not forgive their sins.
text.35: In this verse, Allah asks those who believe, when the command to carry out jihad has been issued and they know that Allah will surely help those who believe, they must feel strong, not discouraged, and never invite the enemy to make peace. They are the people who believe that Muslims will attain a high degree in the sight of Allah. Allah remains with them and will not diminish their reward in the slightest. Allah will not be with the disbelievers, let alone help them, because they are actually Allah's creatures who degrade their own status.
text.36:
Allah encourages those who believe to strive in jihad and spend their wealth in His way, to destroy the enemies of Allah and their enemies, namely the disbelievers of Mecca. They should never be fascinated by the life of this world, causing them to abandon jihad, because the life of this world is only temporary, just a game and amusement. Everything in this world will vanish, except obedience and worship to Allah, because obedience and worship are the means to obtain true life in the Hereafter. From this verse, it can be understood that jihad in the way of Allah is an act of worship that demonstrates obedience and submission to Him. Therefore, perform jihad as you perform other acts of worship.

Furthermore, Allah states that the deeds that can be a true preparation for the Hereafter are believing in Allah, carrying out all His commands and avoiding all His prohibitions, and spending wealth in His way as taught by the Prophet Muhammad. What is required from the wealth spent is only a small portion of the income, not all of it, and given as zakat, sadaqah, ongoing charity (amal jariah), and so on. If they carry out these things, Allah will reward them with manifold rewards in the form of peace of mind in this world, and Paradise in the Hereafter.
text.37:
In this verse, Allah explains one of the reprehensible traits of humans: stinginess and a strong love and desire for wealth. Allah states that He does not ask them to give all their wealth to the weak Muslims. If He were to ask for all of it like that, they would certainly not give it because they are too greedy for wealth and would not give it to the poor. Allah knows this. The more often the request is repeated, the more their hatred and envy towards the poor will increase.

The trait of stinginess has become human nature. It is a trait that comes later, as Allah says:

"And reconciliation is best. And man is inclined to avarice." (an-Nisa'/4: 128)

Allah SWT says:

"And whoever is protected from the stinginess of his soul - it is those who will be the successful." (al-hasyr/59: 9)

In another verse, it is stated that if a person can eliminate or reduce their stinginess, then they will be fortunate in this world and the hereafter.
text.38:
This verse explains that Allah calls upon them to eliminate the trait of stinginess. They are asked to spend their wealth in the way of Allah. It is explained that whoever is stingy, unwilling to spend wealth in the way of Allah, then their stinginess will harm themselves because stinginess will disrupt relationships within society and will erase their rewards, distancing themselves from Allah and Paradise. If people spend, it is not for Allah because He does not need their wealth, for He is All-Sufficient, needing nothing. Spending is actually for their own benefit because Allah will reward it manifold, in addition to the reward whose recompense is Paradise.

Then Allah threatens them by saying that if they turn away, that is, do not believe and are unwilling to fulfill His command by spending, then Allah will destroy them, then replace them with another people who are not like them, namely a people who are willing to spend, strive in jihad, carry out His commands, and avoid His prohibitions.

Narrated by al-Baihaqi, at-Tirmidhi and others from Abu Hurairah who said:

The Messenger of Allah (saw) recited this verse to the end, so the companions asked, "O Messenger of Allah, who are those people who, if we turn away, will replace us and they are not like us?" Then the Messenger of Allah patted Salman's shoulder, then said, "This is the man and his people. By Allah in Whose hand is my soul, if the religion were suspended on the star of Surayya, it would be reached by people from Persia."
